title: 107_s2844
content: The Act may be cited as the "Incentives to Educate American Children (I Teach) Act of 2002". Congress finds that there is a need for 2,000,000 new teachers in the next decade, especially in rural and high-poverty schools. Rural education is crucial in 25 states, and high poverty schools struggle to retain certified teachers. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards was established in 1987. High poverty schools face challenges in retaining certified teachers, with twice the likelihood of not having teachers certified in their fields compared to other schools. The National Board for Professional Teaching Standards, established in 1987, aims to set high standards for accomplished teachers through a rigorous certification process. Over 16,000 teachers nationwide have completed this certification, which has been shown to benefit teachers in the Accomplished Teaching Validation Study. Recent data from the Accomplished Teaching Validation Study shows that teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards outperform their peers on key teaching measures. Teacher salaries have stagnated over the past decade, with many states falling below the national average. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in high-poverty schools and provide tax credits for those who achieve National Board certification. The Act aims to incentivize teachers to work in rural or high-poverty schools and provide tax credits for those who achieve National Board certification. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural schools and certified teachers is provided under section 35 of the Internal Revenue Code. Tax credit of $1,000 is allowed for eligible teachers in rural or high poverty schools for the taxable year. In this section, a tax credit of $1,000 is provided for eligible teachers certified by the National Board for Professional Teaching Standards. For teachers in rural areas or schools with high poverty, the tax credit amount increases to $2,000. An eligible teacher is defined as an individual certified for the academic year. In rural or high-poverty schools, certified teachers receive a $2,000 tax credit. Eligible teachers are K-12 classroom instructors in public schools on a full-time basis. The Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines an eligible academic year as any academic year ending after December 31, 2002. Conforming amendments include changes to section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Tax credit for individuals teaching in high poverty or rural areas and certified teachers. Effective Date: Amendments apply to academic years ending in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2002.
